 ALBANIA - POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION PROJECT Credit and Project Summary Borrower: Republic of Albania. Beneficiaries: Albanian Electroenergetic Corporation (KESH), the Power Corporations of Elbasan, Shkoder and Vlore, and the Ministry of Mineral and Energy Resources. Credit Amount: SDR 19.7 million (US$29.5 million equivalent). Terms: Forty years maturity with a ten-year grace period. Credit proceeds would be lent to the Government at the standard IDA service charge. Onlending terms: Fifteen years maturity including a four-year grace period, at a rate equal to the yield on Albanian Treasury Bills. Project Objectives: (i) improve the overall standard, reliability and efficiency of electric power supply and enhance the efficiency of electricity interchanges with neighboring countries; (ii) reduce unbilled electricity consumption; (iii) establish a regulatory framework; (iv) begin the process of privatizing the power sector in an efficient and non-disruptive way; (v) ensure the financial viability and institutional strength of KESH and the distribution enterprises of Elbasan, Shkoder and Vlore; and (vi) encourage energy conservation and efficiency in electric appliances and buildings. Project Description: (a) power sector regulatory reform and actions leading to privatization and institutional strengthening; (b) technical assistance for: (i) privatization and regulatory training: (ii) management of KESH's financial department, and (iii) engineering, project implementation management and training; and (c) transmission, dispatching system and distribution system investments. Environmental Aspects: The project has been assigned Category B. Major environmental issues identified were: possible presence of PCBs in existing transformers at distribution stations included in the project; and possible PCB contamination of soil and groundwater at KESH-owned transformer stations. An Environmental Management Plan has been prepared. KESH will prepare an action plan for monitoring PCBs, disposing of them and mitigating environmental damage from PCB release.
 - vii - Benefits: The economic rate of return is estimated at 24%. The benefits of the physical components are: (i) reduction in technical transmission and distribution losses; (ii) reduced power outages and improved voitage stability; (iii) increased capacity to transmit and distribute electricity; (iv) improved safe transfers of electricity between Albania and Greece; (v) reduced operating costs and maintenance;and (vi) environmental benefits from reduced need for thermal power generation. The benefits of the institutional components (which were notrquantified) include: (i) reduced non-technical losses; (ii) improved electricity bill collection; (iii) improved financial performance of the Beneficiaries; (iv) a regulatory framework that would provide a suitable environment for private investors; and (v) energy conservation and efficiency improvements in electrical appliances and buildings. Risks: The project is not expected to have detrimental effects on the environment and presents no physical risks, since it involves construction of standard transmission, distribution and dispatching facilities. Delays in project implementation could arise due to inadequate availability of counterpart funds when needed; this risk would be addressed through abolition of the excise tax and adherence to agreed financial covenants. Delays or changes in project scope could result from failure to mobilize the expected cofmancing on time, or to obtain on time the rights-of-way for three transmission lines. These risks would be addressed through provision for resort to IDA's remedies, but even with delays, the project investments are viable. The project could be jeopardized if unpaid electricity consumption increases. This risk would be reduced by implementation of the Power Loss Reduction Project, by strengthened law enforcement and by progressive privatization of the distribution companies. Delays could also be caused by problems arising during the transition from public to private ownership. These would be minimized by joint procurement of equipment items by KESH. The risk of privatization of the entire distribution sector failing is minimized by having first a pilot program involving only three distribution companies and then basing further action on a careful review of experience gained under the pilot program.  ALBANIA POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION PROJECT STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT I. INTRODUCTION 1. Background. The 1990 political changes in Albania were accompanied by a sharp economic contraction. GDP fell by 10% in 1990, 28% in 1991 and 7% in 1992. A sharp turnaround followed the election of a democratic government in March 1992 and the launching of a comprehensive program of stabilization and systemic reforms. By the end of 1994, GDP was about 20% above the 1992 level. Income, including remittances from Albanians abroad, was up 30%. This impressive result was brought about to a large extent by the Albanian Government's courageous implementation of very demanding IMF stand-by and IDA supported structural adjustment programs. One of the Government's most notable achievements in this context has been the complete privatization of agriculture, resulting in a large (30%) increase in agricultural output over the 1992 level, despite the fact that many experts had predicted that the individual plots of land would be too small for significant productivity increases. Both macroeconomic management and private sector development have been exceptionally successful so far. Indeed, the combination of low inflation (10-15% per annum for 1994 and 1995) and rapid growth is unique in the Region. 2. The effective constraint on further development of the economy as a whole and the private sector in particular is now mainly in infrastructure. Infrastructure was already under strain in the late 1980's due to decades of neglect and limited development. This has been exacerbated by an explosion of demand triggered by Albania's opening up to the outside world and the emergence of private sector-led growth. The Government is now beginning to tackle the difficult problem of improving infrastructure services and of privatization of strategic sectors, including public utilities such as power, water supply and telecommunications. To this end, the Government has begun a mass privatization program using a voucher scheme, under which a large number of state-owned industrial enterprises and part of the public utilities are being offered for sale to voucher holders. Where necessary and desirable the involvement of strategic investors would be sought. IDA has provided significant assistance to the Government in helping develop this mass privatization program. 3. The Government believes that privatization is beneficial not only for the usual macroeconomic and efficiency reasons but also for some country-specific reasons. Following the collapse of Albania's extremely repressive communist regime, many citizens felt that whatever belonged to the State was legitimately theirs, including such goods as bread and public utility services. The Government has found it difficult to stop this phenomenon, in part because its administrative capacity, while improving, is still weak. On the other hand, Albanians are willing to respect private property. Hence, the Government has decided to embark on a program
 of privatization of the electricity distribution sector, in the conviction that this will be effective in curbing and eventually eliminating the widespread illegal use of electricity. 4. The Government raised all energy prices sharply in April 1994, so that many of them are now at or above economic cost. Subsidies for household energy were eliminated, the prices of fuel wood and coal were freed from government control, and the prices of most other energy carriers for household use were raised to the economic cost level. These energy price increases have been the steepest experienced anywhere in Central and Eastern Europe, and the Government deserves credit for these courageous steps. However, given the much lower per capita incomes in Albania compared to the rest of Central and Eastern Europe, energy consumption now weighs heavily on household budgets. 5. The Government is following a two-pronged strategy to resolve the illegal consumption problem. First, it is undertaking strong action (publicity campaign, law enforcement through courts and police, etc.) to curb illegal consumption and abetment of it by some of KESH's staff. A similar approach produced good results in the customs service. This is supplemented by major efforts on KESH's part, including a scheme to make staff responsible for decreasing illegal consumption within assigned areas and to provide bonuses for doing so (and penalties for failure). Second, privatization of part or all of the electricity sector is being initiated, starting with the pilot privatization of three distribution companies. If the experience is successful, other distribution companies will be privatized as well, perhaps followed by the generating companies. Private property rights are generally respected in Albania (para 3) and, hence, it is believed that privatization of the distribution part of the sector would result in sharp reductions in illegal consumption. Taken together, these measures constitute a well-designed package to reduce illegal electricity use rapidly to acceptable levels. 6. Electricity demand. Electricity demand within Albania increased sharply in 1993-94 to 3,719 gigawatt-hours (GWh), its highest level ever. Demand increases came primarily from households and small commercial enterprises, much of it for uneconomic uses of electricity such as space heating. The increase in household consumption was due mostly to: (i) imports of large numbers of appliances from abroad, many of which were financed by Albanians living abroad; (ii) the initially very low electricity price; and (iii) the above-mentioned sharp increases in illegal consumption of electricity. Distribution losses grew from 11 % of electricity entering the distribution network in 1989 to 51 % in 1994 and to 65% in March 1995. 7. Failure to control non-technical losses would lead to greatly increased expenses for thermal power generation and imported electricity, increased overloading of transmission and distribution networks leading to frequent outages and equipment damage and a serious risk of major supply failures greater than those that occurred in late 1994 (para 8). As long as this situation goes unchecked electricity "demand" will increase exponentially and investment "requirements" along with it. Investment requirements would climb to about US$150 million per year (8% of GDP) for new generating capacity or electricity imports and repairs to the transmission and distribution systems. Hence the Government's urgent desire to undertake a
 series of measures designed to put an end to this. Adoption of the first set of measures listed in paragraph 5 is starting to have an effect. Because of these measures, and favorable seasonal factors, total distribution losses fell to an average of 44% from June through November 1995. 8. Electricity Emergency of 1994. The additional household and commercial demand, which is heavily skewed towards the hours of peak demand on the power system, explains the surge in peak demand to a record high in December 1994. This caused serious overloading of many transmission networks, transformers and distribution systems in major load centers. The results were excessive technical losses, voltage drops and instability, outages and damages to transformers, cable, meters and other equipment. The vicious circle is that as non-technical losses grow, technical losses increase as well and service deteriorates faster. 9. The electricity emergency was the result of a lack of rainfall combined with the start of the peak load winter season. The transmission and distribution systems, already weak because of many years of under-investment and inadequate maintenance, began to crumble due to a massive increase in electricity usage. Hydropower production (which normally accounts for more than 90% of Albania's electricity supply) had to be reduced to less than one-third of the normal level. In December 1994, the Government imposed a ceiling on electricity supply at about 35% below estimated demand. Production was greatly increased at the thermal power stations and electricity was imported from Greece. However, increased demand meant that during periods when electricity was available distribution networks were overloaded. This resulted in a large number of service interruptions and considerable equipment damage. 10. The emergency underlined the urgent need to strengthen the electricity infrastructure and to reduce technical and non-technical losses. Two current IDA projects, both cofinanced by Switzerland, partly address these needs. The Critical Imports Project (Credit 2404-ALB) financed, inter alia, some urgent repairs of the electricity system and some 36,000 electricity meters. The Power Loss Reduction Project (Credit 2677-ALB), which became effective on June 9, 1995 focuses specifically on reducing non-technical losses through the implementation of a detailed action plan, the purchase and installation of a large number of meters and technical assistance to KESH. The proposed Power Transmission and Distribution Project would finance a major rehabilitation and reinforcement program of the transmission and distribution systems. Furthermore, EBRD approved in November 1994 a project to rehabilitate the Drin River hydropower stations. 11. The proposed project would be Albania's largest project with IDA involvement. The total cost would be US$116.6 million of which $29.5 million would be financed by an IDA credit, $57.6 million by cofinancing provided by OECF, EBRD and the Italian and Swiss Governments, and the remainder by the KESH and the distribution enterprises of Elbasan, Shkoder and Vlore. A complementary transmission project of about $20 million would be supported by the European Investment Bank. 12. Documents and detailed information concerning the sector and the project are in the Project File (Annex 1).
 - 4 - II. THE ENERGY SECTOR A. Energy Resources 13. Albania's energy resources comprise: oil, natural gas, coal, wood and other biomass, peat and hydropower. Remaining proven recoverable oil reserves are estimated at 27 million tons. There are also limited remaining recoverable natural gas reserves estimated at 1.63 billion cubic meters. Production of most of the remaining oil and gas will require enhanced recovery methods. Minable coal reserves in seams thicker than 0.4 meters are 350 million tons, but they are not economic. The standing stock of wood in the forest estate is about 80 million cubic meters; there is much wood and other biomass available for fuel use outside the forest estate, but estimates of the annual sustainable supply vary widely. Peat resources are estimated at 158 million tons, virtually all of which are located in a single deposit near Maliq. Use of peat as a household fuel was investigated but found not to be feasible because of high ash content and marginal economics. While Albania's hydropower potential has not been precisely established, it is thought to be more than three times as large as the amount already developed, which produces 4,000 GWh in a normal hydrological year. Albania's energy resources have been sufficient to supply the country's needs and enable it until recently to be a net energy exporter. B. Past Energy Consumption and Production 14. Variations in total energy consumption from 1982 to 1994 reflected the evolution of the economy over the same period. Consumption grew by 6% from 1982 to 1989, fell by 39% from 1989 to 1992 and then rebounded by 16% to 3 million tons of oil equivalent (toe) in 1994 (Annexes 2.1 and 2.2). 15. Although 1994 energy consumption was about 30% lower than the 1989 peak, per capita consumption of 0.545 toe (0.849 toe including fuel wood) in 1994 was high compared to consumption in countries with similar per capita incomes. The 43 low income countries listed in World Development Report 1994, with average per capita GNP of US$390 in 1992 (compared to $303 in Albania in 1994), had an average per capita energy consumption of 0.338 toe (excluding fuelwood). Given that Albania's energy intensive industries have greatly reduced production since 1989, its relatively high per capita energy consumption is due to high household use of energy, especially electricity. 16. From 1982 to 1989, domestically produced crude oil and fuelwood were the main sources of supply at about 1.2 million toe each per year. Hydropower generation increased by 1986 to about 1 million toe with the commissioning of the Komani hydropower station. Coal production increased to over 0.5 million toe, but natural gas production fell to about 0.2 million toe as a result of a gas field fire. After 1989, the sharp contraction of the economy combined with the effects of insufficient previous maintenance and outdated equipment led to a virtual collapse of energy production in Albania. Production of oil, coal and natural gas fell by 53%, 91 % and 78% respectively between 1989 and 1994. Fuelwood production estimates for this period are
 - 5 - uncertain, with a reduction in officially allowed supply thought to have been largely offset by increased illegal cutting. Hydropower was the only source of supply that was maintained at a satisfactory level after 1989, but it too was at risk because of insufficient maintenance and variable rainfall. 17. Prior to 1993, Albania was a net exporter of energy. By 1994 net imports reached 13% of total consumption, mainly because of greatly increased imports of diesel oil and to a lesser extent gasoline and kerosene. C. Sector Institutions and Management 18. Responsibilities for energy are shared among several entities at the government level. The Ministry of Mineral and Energy Resources (MME) has responsibility for: the Albanian Oil and Gas Corporation (Albpetrol); the National Petroleum Agency, which issues licenses for petroleum exploration and production; the Albanian Electroenergetic Corporation (KESH); and the coal mine enterprises. The Ministry of Construction, Housing and Territory Adjustment is responsible for the Executive Agency for Energy Resources for the Population, which prepares and implements policies for household energy, such as arranging for imports of kerosene and stoves. The National Committee of Energy under the Council of Ministers has responsibility for carrying out analyses of energy policy, compiling energy statistics, making forecasts, and liaising with foreign governments and international organizations on energy matters. The Ministry of Finance has the lead responsibility for energy tax policy. Energy price decisions are made by the Council of Ministers. The Committee for Environmental Protection and Preservation, a semi-autonomous committee within the Ministry of Health, is responsible for preparing and implementing environmental protection measures affecting the energy sector. D. Sector Strategy 19. Because of limited resources the Goverrnent is fightly giving first priority to rehabilitation of existing facilities in the power and petroleum subsectors. This emphasis is evident in the 1995-97 Public Investment Program. The Government has also begun institutional reforms in these subsectors which would lead to privatization of Albpetrol and KESH (para 52). In the petroleum subsector, contracts have been given to foreign oil companies for off-shore exploration and efforts are under way to contract out exploration, enhanced recovery and rehabilitation activities on-shore. A Petroleum Law is in place to provide the framework for private sector involvement in petroleum. Substantial downsizing of the coal industry has already taken place, and the remaining mines are being studied for restructuring or closure. Particular attention has been given to meeting space heating requirements of households during the cold winter months. Arrangements were made for imports of kerosene, liquified petroleum gas (LPG) and stoves. During 1993 private suppliers of wood were made eligible to receive the same subsidy as state enterprises and to compete against state enterprises in auctions of rights to cut wood in specified areas. There was a strong response, resulting in increased fuelwood deliveries to cities. However, because it was easy for households to steal electricity, demand for fuelwood was limited. A National Environmental Action Plan was prepared with technical
 - 6 - assistance managed by IDA. Among the priorities are measures to ensure that forests are exploited in a sustainable way so as to avoid deforestation leading to soil erosion. E. Energy Prices 20. Over the past three years the Government has made rapid progress in raising all energy prices from very low levels. Prices as of March 1994 were already at or above cost for gasoline, diesel oil, fuel oil, kerosene for non-household use and coal for non-household use. On April 1, 1994, Government subsidies for household energy were eliminated, the prices of fuelwood and coal for households were freed, and the prices of kerosene and LPG were fixed at cost covering levels. Energy prices in Albania are shown in Annex 2.3. 21. Electricity Prices. Prior to April 1, 1994 households in large cities paid 0.8 leks per kWh for an initial block of consumption per month (250 kWh in large cities and less elsewhere) and 3 leks per kWh for all additional consumption. On April 1, the price for all household consumption was raised to 4.5 leks per kWh. The price is now at or above the average household price in nearly all other Central Europe countries. 22. The Government has implemented a scheme to compensate households for an estimated 75% of the household energy price increases by means of increases in wages, pensions, unemployment benefits and welfare payments. The amount of compensation given to each family depends on the type of employment of family members, whether they are unemployed, or on pension, etc. It is independent of the amount of energy purchased. Financing was provided initially mainly by increasing the excise taxes on energy, especially electricity. The Government takes the difference between the retail price and 2.4 leks per kWh (from July 1, 1995) for all electricity sales within Albania. The 1994 tariff changes raised the consumption weighted average electricity price within Albania from 1.4 to 3.8 leks per kWh. Therefore, on average 1.4 leks per kWh of sales go to the Government as excise tax. One disadvantage of the present compensation scheme is that for household consumers the compensation is now an integral part of wages, pensions, etc., and in practice they can still receive the compensation while getting electricity for free illegally. 23. The 1994 electricity tariff reform also raised prices for private commercial and industrial customers to more than 4 leks per kWh (Annex 2.3), depending on voltage level, but left prices for large state-owned mining, petroleum and metallurgical industries at 2.1 leks per kWh or lower. A logical next step in tariff reform is to eliminate the economically unjustified distinction between state and private industrial consumers. 24. The Government intends to adjust the level and structure of electricity prices over the next several years to reflect economic costs. Long-run marginal costs are estimated to average about 4.6 US cents per kWh for generation, 0.8 cents for transmission and 2.2 cents for distribution, giving a total of 7.5 cents. These estimates are fairly rough at this stage given the huge uncertainties pertaining to future demand. Tariff structure refinements are expected to be made on the basis of a detailed electricity tariff study being carried out under EBRD's project
 to rehabilitate hydropower stations. The Government raised prices for state-owned industries at the beginning of 1996 so that the consumption-weighted average non-household price is 4 leks per kWh. The Government has agreed to consult with IDA by April 1, 1996 on the recommendations and proposed timetable for implementation of the tariff adjustments recommended in the Electricity Tariff Study, and promptly implement an action program based on acceptable recommendations from the study in accordance with a timetable acceptable to IDA. F. Energy Conservation and Efficiency Improvements 25. Since 1991 there have been massive imports of low-efficiency electrical appliances for household and commercial use, and the large-scale arrival of air conditioners has reportedly begun. The recent energy price increases combined with an effective campaign to reduce illegal electricity consumption (para 5 and 31) could lead to greatly increased energy bills for households. These bills could be reduced by use of higher efficiency appliances and by improved insulation of buildings. However, consumers may not have sufficient information about appliance efficiencies and building insulation to guide their purchase decisions. The Government agreed to carry out an energy conservation and efficiency study by June 30, 1996, under terms of reference satisfactory to IDA, and by January 1, 1997 begin to implement an action program based on acceptable recommendations agreed with IDA. The study report would encourage the use of high-efficiency household appliances and start improving insulation of existing and new buildings. Among the options to be examined would be appliance labelling, taxes on low-efficiency appliances, publicity campaigns, training of housing technicians, and introduction of energy efficiency provisions in a national building code. The study would measure efficiencies of appliances currently being used in Albania, identify appropriate efficiency improvements for buildings, propose standards for a building code and identify appropriate policy actions. The UNDP would provide grant financing for this study if requested by the Government. G. IDA Activities in the Energy Sector 26. IDA's first credit to Albania, for the Critical Imports Project, includes financing of US$14.1 million, plus $2.6 million of parallel financing by the Swiss Government, for urgent repairs to the Drin River hydropower stations and the transmission and distribution systems. The power component is being carried out successfully. A contract for meters costing $1.8 million is also being financed from the Critical Imports Project. A Power Loss Reduction Project (US$ 5 million IDA credit and US$2.5 million Swiss Government grant) was approved in January 1995. It focuses on reduction of non-technical electricity losses through the large scale purchase of meters and implementation of an action plan. 27. An Energy Sector Review was prepared in 1993. IDA managed technical assistance has included: (i) a feasibility study for rehabilitation, upgrading and expansion of the power transmission and distribution systems and related dispatching facilities (financed by Italy); (ii) a power subsector organization study (Switzerland); (iii) training to help KESH establish a
 - 8 - modem accounting system (Switzerland); (iv) a peat supply feasibility study ( Japan); (v) a study of the economic feasibility of making briquettes from sawdust (Netherlands); (vi) testing of stoves available in Albania (IDA); (vii) estimation of the demand and sustainable supply of fuelwood (IDA); (viii) a household energy survey (Netherlands); (ix) a space heating study (Netherlands); and (x) legal assistance to prepare an Electricity Law, a Regulatory Law, a model Distribution License and a Bulk Power Supply Agreement (UNIDO). III. THE POWER SUBSECTOR A. Past Power Consumption and Supply 28. Electricity demand within Albania (net generation minus net exports) grew by 33% in 1993 and 1994 to a record high 3,719 GWh (Annex 3.1). This growth was due mainly to demand increases by households and small commercial enterprises, which imported large numbers of appliances from abroad, many of which were financed by Albanians living abroad, and made widespread resort to illegal use of electricity. Much of the consumption was for uneconomic uses such as space heating. Billed household demand grew from 270 GWh in 1989 to 780 GWh in 1994. Non-technical losses (mostly unbilled use by households and other small consumers) grew from a negligible level in 1989 to an estimated 912 GWh in 1994.' The additional household and commercial demand, which is heavily skewed towards the hours of peak demand, explains the surge in peak load to 801 MW in December 1994 and the fall in system load factor from 67% in 1988-1990 to 50% in 1992. The increase to 54% in 1994 is partly explained by rationing imposed during December 1994 (para 29). 29. A severe lack of rainfall in late 1994 forced KESH to reduce electricity production from the Drin River hydropower stations to less than one-third of their normal level. The shortfall was made up partly by additional thermal power production and imports. Since the transmission lines to former Yugoslavia were out of operation because of the political events there, and electricity supplies from Greece were limited, rationing was imposed temporarily.  - 38 - VII. ECONOMIC JUSTIFICATION A. Benefits and Costs 116. The institutional components of the proposed project would provide the following benefits: (i) reduction in non-technical losses resulting in increased electricity revenue and reduced uneconomic electricity use; (ii) improved electricity bill collection; (iii) improved financial performance of KESH and the pilot distribution companies; (iv) a regulatory framework that would provide a welcoming environment for private investors and operators; and (v) energy conservation and efficiency improvements in electrical appliances and buildings. These benefits have not been quantified for purposes of the economic rate of return calculation. 117. The physical components would provide the following benefits: (i) reduction in technical transmission and distribution losses; (ii) enhanced reliability through reduction in power outages and improvement in voltage stability; (iii) increase in capacity to transmit and distribute electricity; (iv) improved assurance of safe transfers of energy through the Albania-Greece interconnection (an outage on this interconnection at a time when electricity imports are needed would impose a large cost on Albanian consumers); (v) reduction in operating costs and maintenance because of reduced need to repair damaged equipment; and (vi) environmental benefits resulting from a reduced need for power produced by existing thermal plants using high- sulfur heavy fuel oil. 118. Quantitative estimates in gigawatt-hours were made for reductions in technical losses and outages. These reductions were estimated by taking the difference between two system simulation results of two scenarios based on the demand figures of 1994, one assuming implementation of the proposed project, the other without. This approach yields conservative estimates since no account was taken of the fact that an increase in demand on the unstrengthened system would result in higher losses. Increased supply capacity, which would be a byproduct of the investments needed for system strengthening, would provide a benefit if there were an increase in demand. However, this benefit was not evaluated because of the large uncertainty about demand growth (para 39). 119. The loss reductions in transmission were valued at the long-run marginal cost of generation; in distribution at the long-run marginal cost of generation plus transmission. The benefit of reduced outages was measured by the outage reduction in kilowatt hours valued at a cost of unserved energy conservatively estimated at US$ 0.25 per kWh. Before choosing this figure an estimate was made of the cost of operating a backup diesel generator during periods of outage. On the basis of an estimated average 243 hours of outage per year in the areas that would benefit from the proposed project, this cost would be US$0.53 per kWh. Since only a fraction of consumers affected by outages buy backup generators, it was decided to fix the cost of unserved energy at the much lower value of US$0.25 per kWh. This figure was chosen at
 - 39 - a level below estimates of costs of unserved electrical energy for other countries in order to avoid any possible bias towards overestimating the economic rate of return. The costs to be compared to the above benefits are the estimated financial costs of the proposed project excluding price contingencies. There would be no import duties on equipment imported under the project. Shadow prices were not used in the base case since the differences from actual prices would be small and the estimates subject to considerable uncertainties. For example, the shadow exchange rate would likely differ from the actual rate by no more than 10%. The main source of distortion which would in principle justify a shadow price below the actual, the import tariff, is only about 10% of the value of imports on average. 120. Internal economic rates of return were calculated for all the individual project components for which benefit estimates were made and for the total project. The estimated internal rate of return for the total project is 24%, which is higher than the opportunity cost of capital for Albania, taken as 12%. Sensitivity tests were carried out with respect to changes in key parameters. The changes needed to reduce the rate of return to 12% are: 70% less outage reduction, or 80% higher project costs, or a five-year delay in benefits. With zero loss reduction the rate of return would be 18%. Use of a shadow exchange rate 10% lower than the actual would reduce the rate of return to 22%. Detailed results are given in Annex 7.1. B. Risks 121. The project is not expected to have detrimental effects on the environment and presents no physical risks, since construction and rehabilitation of standard transmission, distribution and dispatching facilities are involved. Delays in project implementation could arise due to inadequate availability of counterpart funds when needed; this risk would be addressed through abolition of the excise tax and adherence to agreed financial covenants. Delays or changes in project scope could result from failure to mobilize the expected cofinancing on time, or to obtain on time the rights-of-way for three transmission lines. These risks would be addressed through provision for resort to IDA's remedies, but even with delays, the project investments are viable. The project could be jeopardized if unpaid electricity consumption continues to increase. This risk would be reduced by implementation of the Power Loss Reduction Project, by strengthened law enforcement and by privatization. Delays could also be caused by problems arising during the transition from public to private ownership. These would be minimized by joint procurement of equipment items by KESH. The risk of privatization of the entire distribution sector failing is minimized by having first a pilot program involving only three distribution companies and then base further action on a careful review of experience gained under the pilot program. The risks are discussed further in Annex 7.2.

The present bulk power transmission system of the Albanian Electric Power System is composed of a mesh 220 kV network, which serves through six substations the 110/35 kV subtransmission facilities. The 1 10 kV transmission lines are operated as radial circuits. 2. The 220 kV system's primary function is the interconnection of the three large hydro power plants on the Drin River, in the northern area of Albania, to the major load centers of Tirana, Elbasan, and Fier in the central region of Albania. The total capacity of the Drin River hydroelectric plants is 1,350 MW, which is approximately 93 percent of the total hydroelectric capacity of Albania of 1,444 MW. The thermal generating capacity is only 218 MW. The largest thermal plant at Fier has a capacity of 160 MW. 3. The 220 kV network is interconnected with the former Yugoslavian network (at two tie points) and with the Greek network through a 220/400 kV autotransformer. The 220 kV lines have a total length of 1, 100 km. The thermal limit of the 220 kV lines ranges from 270 to 380 MVA. 4. The radial 110 kV transmission lines are served from six 220/110 kV substations. The autotransformers of these substations have a total capacity 870 MVA. None of these transformers are equipped with automatic tap changing facilities. Further, no capacitors are installed in these substations. The 110 kV lines have a total length of 1,180 km. Their thermal limit ranges from 65 MVA to 120 MVA. These limited capacities result in excessive voltage drops, overload conditions, and excessive losses on key 110 kV lines. The 110 kV system serves the system load through some 60 substations, which are normally equipped with two or three transformers ranging in capacity from 3.2 MVA to 20 MVA. None of these transformers are equipped with automatic tap changing facilities. 5. Most of the equipment in the 220 and 110 kV substations is of older Chinese, Russian, or Yugoslavian manufacture. Many substations, as a result, require substantial rehabilitation. However, spare parts are no longer available. Furthermore, there has not been adequate rehabilitation, reinforcement, and development of the transmission facilities, particularly of the 110 kV, to meet current requirements. This situation has persisted for fifteen years resulting in serious reliability problems and uneconomic operations.
 - 61 - Annex 5.1 Page 2 of 5 Rehabilitation and Reinforcement Plan 6. A Power Transmission System Feasibility Study, prepared by Electroconsult of Italy in 1993, developed a long-term plan for the rehabilitation, upgrading, and expansion of the Albanian transmission system to provide for reliable and economic operation by the year 2000 and to meet expected load demand forecasted for the year 2005. 7. It was established at the outset of the transmission study that the system would be designed based on the following criteria: (i) the 110 kV should to the extent feasible be interconnected to operate as a mesh similar to the 220 kV; (ii) a single contingency including the outage of a 220 kV line, a 110 kV line or a substation transformer should not cause a thermal overload or the curtailment of load; (iii) new 110 kV transformers should be either 16, 25 or 40 MVA with an overload capability of 30 percent and be supplied with automatic tap changing under load equipment; (iv) the minimum and maximum operating range of the 110 kV shall be 105 kV and 125 kV with a normal level of 117 kV; and the minimum or maximum voltage level shall not be exceeded for any single contingency; (v) the minimum and maximum operating range of the 220 kV shall be 209 kV and 245 kV with a normal level of 240 kv; and the minimum or maximum voltage level shall not be exceeded for any single contingency; and (vi) the system shall not cascade in to a major outage for a three phase fault that would result in the loss of the largest generator or loss of a major 220 kV line. 8. Simulations of the operation of the Albanian power system demonstrated that the existing 220 kV bulk transmission system, in its present configuration, is adequate to meet the load requirements of the year 2005. The major problems are almost exclusively due to the inadequacy of the 110 kV transmission facilities and the limitation of the 220/110 kV transformer capacity. 9. Based on the study, system components required rehabilitation and reinforcement were identified and the following transmission system rehabilitation and upgrading program was prepared:

The operation of the Albanian electric power system is controlled and coordinated through a National Dispatch Center (NDC). A second level of control is provided through 11 Regional Dispatch Centers (RDCs). The personnel of the RDC's are the same as those that perform normal power plant and substation operating and maintenance activities. 2. The NDC, located in Tirana, is responsible for monitoring and analysis of real-time system conditions, operations planning, reliability assessment, interchange negotiations and fault and protection operations. The NDC has decision-making authority and works closely with the personnel in the 11 RDCs to provide for the overall coordination and control of the Albanian electric power system. 3. The RDC personnel are responsible for notifying the NDC of system disturbances and alarms, the retransmission of NDC dispatching orders and the collection of historical data. These activities are in addition to normal plant and substation operating and maintenance activities performed by the RDC personnel. Communications between the NDC and 11 RDCs is accomplished by telephone. The NDC relies almost completely on the RDCs for real-time information regarding the present operating status of the system. In addition, the reliability of the telephone system for NDC-RDC communication is poor. 4. A Yugoslavian manufactured load frequency control system is operational at the Vau j Dejes hydroelectric power station. The actual interchange flows on each interconnection are transmitted to the station for use by the load frequency control system. The interchange flows also are transmitted to the NDC. A local reading of frequency is available at the NDC. No regulating signals are sent to the NDC. When required, the regulating parameters are adjusted by the Vau j Dejes RDC operator in accordance with instructions from the NDC. The inability to directly set load frequency control parameters results in serious deviations in interchange schedules. 5. The NDC dispatching staff has two personal computers and a terminal to the corporate mainframe computer. These are used for load flow calculations to analysis current and future system conditions and for computing daily and annual energy production. This facility does not meet standard security requirements. Further, it is remote from the 220 kV and power line carrier facilities increasing the serial communications links to the NDC and in turn decreasing system reliability.

The proposed system control facilities will provide the opportunity to significantly increase the operating reliability and economy of the electric power system. At present, no information is available in real-time regarding the primary generation and transmission facilities. This makes it impossible for the operators to quickly analyze current conditions and to take appropriate action to maintain operating reliability and economy. The proposed data acquisition facilities along with the state estimation program will provide the necessary real-time data to meet this requirement. The proposed load frequency system, will enable the operators to adhere more closely to interchange schedules, increasing the availability of generation for export.

The present power distribution facilities of the Albanian Electric Power System serve over 600,000 industry, commercial, and residential customers throughout Albania. The current population of Albania is about 3.1 million people. The average number of users per square kilometer is approximately a third of typical populated countries, and the number of inhabitants per square kilometer about half. These lower user and population densities require greater investment per customer. The primary cables and overhead feeders of the distribution system are either 10 kV or 6 kV. The distribution facilities are supplied primarily from the 35 kV subtransmission system, which in turn is supplied from the 220 kV and 110 kV systems. 2. The present distribution facilities are in extremely poor condition due to the long period of isolation, as well as the poor economic conditions of the country itself. The distribution equipment obtained from the former Soviet Union up to 1973, and from China starting in 1973, is for the most part 20 to 30 years old and to a large degree obsolete. Extreme overload conditions resulted during the severe winter of 1991-1992 when extensive use was made of electric heating that here-to-fore had been restricted by the lack of electric heaters and other appliances. At the same time, there was widespread tampering of metering and supply facilities that lead to an estimated 40 percent loss of total supply to the system, with about half of the losses being non-technical. These conditions resulted in extensive damage to the distribution facilities, particularly in the main cities. Approximately 30 percent of the existing 35/10 kV and 35/6 kV transformers were destroyed, many substations were set on fire and a large number of low voltage (LV) cables were damaged. The technical losses of those facilities that remained in operation were three times higher than normal due to the excessive loading conditions. Rehabilitation and Upgrading Plan 3. A Power Distribution System Feasibility Study was prepared by Electroconsult of Italy in 1993. It was recognized at the outset that to meet long term demands with satisfactory service reliability, it would require substantial investments (estimated at about US$200 million) in a relative short time period. A plan was devised that could be financeable. This plan followed the following guidelines: (i) the distribution facilities serving the three main cities of Tirana, Shkoder, and Durres would be rehabilitated and upgraded to meet load demands for the year 2005 and provide a satisfactory level of service in the future. In view of the extent of the requirements to replace obsolete and inadequate facilities, consideration was given to gradually introducing 20 kV as a substitute for the existing double voltage levels of 35/10 kV and 35/6 kV currently used; (ii) the distribution facilities serving a second group of smaller cities of Elbasan,
 - 69 - Annex 5.3 Page 2 of 3 Fier, Vlore, Korce, Berati, Diber, Lushnje, Gjirokaster, Rescen, Lac, Sarande, and Lezhe would be rehabilitated to meet load demands for the year 2005 by replacing only those components that are totally inadequate; (iii) the remaining portion of the distribution facilities serving low density and rural areas would be kept in operation utilizing equipment obtained from the replacement of facilities that originally served the main or secondary cities; and (iv) 110/20 kV and 110/35 kV transformers will be equipped with tap-changing-under-load facilities to compensate for 110 kV voltage variations and to independently regulate the 20 kV and 35 kV bus voltages. In the cases where the existing 110/35 kV/ transformers are to be retained in operation, reactive compensation will be used to regulate bus voltages. Distribution Networks Rehabilitation Under the Project 4. The rehabilitation of selected distribution networks is needed to prevent further damage. This is a part of the above rehabilitation program. Estimated cost is about US$60 million. The most critical areas in Tirana, Durres, Shkoder, Elbasan, Vlore, and few other major load centers were selected. Distribution networks in these areas are between 25 and 45 years old, were designed for much smaller loads than those they are presently serving, and are seriously overloaded. The interruption rate of supply to these areas as the result of cable faults is 100 to 120 failures per 100 kilometers per year. This is about 16 to 20 times the European experience of 6 failures per 100 kilometers per year. In order to avoid further deterioration, improve distribution reliability, and reduce technical losses in these distribution networks, urgent rehabilitation and reinforcement are required. This component would include introduction of a 20 kV single medium-voltage level to replace the existing multiple medium-voltage levels of 6, 10, 35/10, and 35/6 kV in the distribution grids of Tirana, Durres and Shkoder, where load densities are highest and facilities are aging, and rehabilitation of the 35 kV and 35/6 kV networks in a few selected major load centers: (i) Tirana: the areas selected for rehabilitation in Tirana are located in the northern, eastern, and western parts of the city supplied by Tirana, Selite, and Traktori 220/110 kV primary substations.  - 77 - Annex 5.7 Attachment II Page 1 of 4 ALBANIA - POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION PROJECT Project Management Consulting Services: Terms of Reference Background 1. The Albanian electric power system is experiencing serious operating problems due to insufficient development of its subtransmission system and distribution network, and the lack of required rehabilitation and reinforcement of its facilities. The lack of development, rehabilitation, and maintenance has persisted for a period of fifteen years. Present facilities are significantly reducing operating reliability. Three major existing problems are: (a) serious overloading of 110 kV subtransmission facilities and distribution networks resulting in heavy losses, voltage drops, power outages and the failure of many distribution transformers; (b) abnormal power factor values due to the lack of reactive supply capability on the subtransmission and distribution systems; (c) outdated system control and protection equipment and very deficient communication facilities threatening system safety and reliability. Without an intensive rehabilitation of the system, there is a significant risk of major breakdowns. 2. The objective of the Transmission and Distribution Project is to assist KESH to carry out long delayed rehabilitation and reinforcement of the existing power system facilities in order to improve the overall standard and reliability of the electric power service provided by the KESH power system, to reduce the occurrence of power system outages and losses, and to enhance the efficiency of electricity interchanges with neighboring countries. The project would assist in urgently needed rehabilitation and upgrading of transmission, distribution and dispatching facilities located in various parts of the country, particularly in the load centers of Tirana, Shkoder, Durres, Elbasan and Vlore, and other major load centers of Fieri, Vlore, Berati, Diber, Lac and Saranda, where the need is most urgent. Project Description 3. The Transmission and Distribution Project consists of: (i) a new double-circuit 220 kV line of about 4 km interconnecting Elbasan 1 and Elbasan 2 substations (financed by EBRD); (ii) a new double-circuit 110 kV transmission line of about 105 km between Elbasan, Cerrik, and Korce, and addition of reactive power compensation capacity in the system up to about 30 MVAR (financed by EBRD); (iii) reconstruction and reinforcement of the 110 kV ring connection between Tirana, Selite and Traktori substations (financed by EBRD); (iv) a new 220/110 kV substation in Durres (financed by Swiss Government);
 - 78 - Annex 5.7 Attachment II Page 2 of 4 (v) rehabilitation and reinforcement of two 220 kV, and sixteen 110 kV existing primary substations (financed by OECF); (vi) upgrading of system control facilities (including National Dispatch Center and Remote Terminal Units; financed by Italian Government); (vii) rehabilitation of distribution networks in major cities and load centers, including Tirana, Durres, Fier, Berati, Diber, Lac and Saranda, and three pilot distribution companies for privatization, i.e., Shkoder, Elbasan and Vlora (except Tirana to be financed by OECF, other distribution networks will be financed by IDA; and (viii) spares and special tools for transmission and distribution systems (financed by EBRD). Engineering and Procurement 4. KESH has the capability to carry out most of the engineering and construction supervision required for the transmission and distribution works. However, in view of the magnitude and complexity of KESH's existing and future operations, there is a need for intensive consulting services to assist KESH in detailed design and engineering for the new transmission lines, Durres substation and system control facilities. EBRD is providing technical assistance for the detailed design and preparation of bidding documents for the transmission facilities. Swiss and Italian Governments will provide engineering services through turn-key contracts for the Durres substation and system control facilities, respectively. Engineering for rehabilitation works are being carried out by KESH's engineers. Procurement of goods and services for the above project components financed by the World Bank, EBRD, Italy, and Switzerland would follow respectively procedures set out by the World Bank, OECF, EBRD, the Government of Italy, and the Government of Switzerland. Project Implementation 5. The Project covers the rehabilitation and reinforcement program for the Albanian transmission and distribution systems for the period 1996 through year 2000. KESH would be responsible for the execution of the Project. A Project Management Unit (PMU), will be set up under KESH's management and be responsible for the rehabilitation and reinforcement of the transmission system and distribution networks. An office of PMU, responsible for day to day management of the Unit, will be established. The PMU would be assisted by consultant services under this Terms of Reference. The contract for this consultant services will be signed between KESH and the provider. The implementation of the sub-projects would be the responsibility of the local transmission and distribution entities. Procurement would be centralized and carried out by KESH's Procurement Department, under the PMU's supervision, and deliveries would be made directly to the regional warehouses.

Improvement of KESH's financial management is now recognized to be a critical necessity. The entity is a major source of revenue for the Treasury but apprears to be, at the same time, in an almost desperate liquidity situation. Reduction and eventual elimination of the excise tax would leave KESH with larger amounts of money at its disposal, which must be wisely spent and carefully accounted for. The management of KESH needs to have access to reliable and up to date financial information. They, and KESH's lenders, need to receive unqualified year-end financial statements in a timely fashion. The first attempt to significantly improve KESH's financial management, which was grant-financed by the Swiss Government, did not succeed. Although a new chart of accounts was prepared, introduction was not possible, primarily due to a lack of qualified counterpart staff. The major investments proposed to be undertaken in the electricity sector, and the recent corporatization of KESH, demand that this situation be rectified urgently. Given that it has been proven to be impossible to achieve this with existing staff and locally available expertise, this must be done with outside help. Such help must be of sufficieiit magnitude to provide a critical mass of people that is able to achieve tangible results relatively quickly. Hence, under the IDA credit an amount of US$3.5 million would be allocated for this purpose. KESH would issue invitations for proposals, which could be bid for by accounting firms and electric utilities worldwide. The expatriate experts would have to reside in Albania for the duration of their contract. At the end of their term, the experts should have trained an adequate number of local staff to be able to gradually take over the financial management of KESH.  - 134 - Annex 7.2 Page 1 of 3 ALBANIA - POWER TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION PROJECT Evaluation of Project Scenarios The project risks may be clarified by considering the consequences of the following scenarios: (i) Procurement delays. These delays would not affect the project rate of return in the typical case since they would occur prior to expenditures being made and hence would not increase the period between expenditures and benefits. However, delays in procurement of particular items would lengthen the period between expenditures and benefits for linked items that have already been procured but cannot be put into operation until the particular items are installed. The rate of return is highly robust with respect to such delays. It would take a five year delay in benefits after the investments are made to reduce the rate of return to 12%. Although the rate of return is robust with respect to delays, there would be an adverse impact on electricity consumers resulting from postponement of improvements in supply reliability. (ii) Delayed availability of counterpart funds. This would hold up the installation of equipment procured under the project and thereby increase the period between expenditures and benefits. As mentioned above, the rate of return is highly robust with respect to such delays. (iii) Delayed or reduced cofinancing. Since EBRD has already approved its part of the project, this scenario concerns only possible delays or reductions by Italy, Switzerland and OECF. Because of only partial interdependence among project components, it would be possible to accommodate delays or reductions in most of the components of the cofinanciers without causing adverse impact on rates of return for the other components of the project. However, if the Swiss Govemment were to delay, it would be desirable for another cofinancier to take responsibility for technical assistance for the Project Management Unit, since this assistance is needed from the time the project starts. Reduced cofinancing would require a reduction in project scope and could entail some reallocation of project components among the remaining cofinanciers, including IDA, in order to ensure that the highest priority components proceed. In particular, if OECF decided not to cofinance, it would be desirable for the remaining cofinanciers to make adjustments in order to come up with at least partial financing for the Tirana distribution system and the critically needed transmission system equipment included in the OECF part of the project. If the Swiss Government decided not to cofinance, it would probably be desirable for another cofinancier to finance the Durres substation because of its critical importance for removing bottlenecks in supplies to Durres and Tirana. To summarize, delayed or reduced cofinancing could cause inconvenient changes in project scope and the
 - 135 - Annex 7.2 Page 2 of 3 reallocation of components among cofinanciers, but would not adversely affect the project rate of return. (iv) Delay in securing the rights of way for three transmission lines. This delay would not affect the rates of return for these components, nor for the other components of the project. But it would mean a delay in bringing relief to consumers from transmission system outages. (v) Increase in unpaid electricity consumption. This would lead to an increase in demand resulting in increased outages originating in unstrengthened parts of the power system (e.g., generation) and/or investments that would not be required if consumers had been forced to pay for their electricity consumption. The project would still yield the same benefits in terms of reduced transmission and distribution system outages and losses at any given level of demand compared to the existing system. But this improvement would not be noticeable to consumers if the increased demand leads to outages in the generation system or overloading of the new transmission and distribution facilities. Despite the possibility of these outcomes, it would not be appropriate to delay the project for the following reasons: (i) the current outages are causing much equipment damage which could be avoided by the strengthened capacity and protective equipment provided by the project; (ii) continued unreliable electricity supply will hamper economic growth and lead to costly expenditures on backup generators; (iii) there are signs that loss reduction campaigns are beginning to succeed (para. 33); and (iv) the project is needed to meet the demand expected to result when unpaid electricity consumption is brought under control. An estimate was made of the economic rate of return from proceeding with the project now compared to postponing by one year. The benefits come from advancing by one year the reduction in transmission and distribution losses and outages. The cost is the loss in interest, measured at the estimated opportunity cost of capital of 12%, resulting from advancing by one year the use of project investment funds in the project. The rate of return was estimated to be 160%. This estimate is conservative since it does not take account of the benefit of avoided equipment damages. (vi) Problems relating to the transition to private ownership. Two scenarios are considered for the three pilot companies. (a) Possible delays in implementing and reporting on their project components because of inexperience with Bank procurement and disbursement procedures, modern accounting techniques, etc. In order to avoid these difficulties KESH has agreed to handle procurement and disbursements on behalf of the pilot companies for equipment purchased under the project and to provide assistance in other areas (para. 59). However, there may still be a need for considerable supervision by Bank staff. (b) Possible financial
 - 136 - Annex 7.2 Page 3 of 3 difficulties leading, for example, to delay in paying KESH for electricity supplies. These difficulties could arise if the companies fail to meet their loss reduction targets. However, the pilot companies have been granted generous distribution margins, and the distribution licenses (para. 58) have provisions to deal with such situations. The likelihood of either of these scenarios occurring will be reduced when strategic investors are found for these companies. (c) Another scenario, which is in fact expected, is that other distribution companies may be separated from KESH and privatized during the period of project disbursements. While this outcome may require some amendments to the legal agreements with IDA and other cofinanciers, similar arrangements could be made with these distribution companies for implementation of the project as with the pilot companies.

doc.abstracts: The Power Transmission and Distribution Project's objectives include: i) improving the overall standard, reliability and efficiency of electric power supply and enhance the efficiency of electricity interchanges with neighboring countries; ii) reducing unbilled electricity consumption; iii) establishing a regulatory framework for the power sector; iv) beginning the process of privatizing the Albanian Electroenergetic Corporation (KESH) in an efficient and non-disruptive way; v) ensuring the financial viability and institutional strength of KESH and the Power Corporations of Elbasan, Shkoder and Vlore; and vi) encouraging energy conservation and efficiency in electric appliances and buildings. The project components include: a) power sector regulatory reform and actions leading to privatization and institutional strengthening; b) technical assistance for: i) privatization and regulatory training of the Ministry of Mineral and Energy Resources (MME), ii) management of KESH's financial department, and iii) engineering, project implementation management and training; and c) transmission, dispatching system and distribution system investments.
